newsitem.title: QATAR: EU asks GCC to push Iran to lift Rushdie fatwa.
newsitem.headline: EU asks GCC to push Iran to lift Rushdie fatwa.

text.p: The European Union asked Gulf Arab states on Monday to use their influence with Iran to have a religious edict, or fatwa, calling for the death of British author Salman Rushdie rescinded.

"On the EU's behalf I urge our Gulf Cooperation partners to do what they can to resolve the growing and more and more unacceptable problem of the fatwa against Salman Rushdie," Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van Mierlo said at an EU-Gulf Cooperation Council Ministerial Meeting and Joint Council. Van Mierlo is the chairman of the EU Ministerial Council.
The Gulf Cooperation Council groups Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Bahrain and Qatar.
Iran's late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in 1989 issued the fatwa ordering the killing of Rushdie for alleged blasphemy against Islam in his book "The Satanic Verses".
The Iranian government says the fatwa is a purely religious matter unrelated to the government. Tehran said it would not seek to kill Rushdie, but that it cannot rescind a religious ruling.

Van Mierlo said the edict was "totally unacceptable" because it violated all canons of international behaviour and rights. "That's (the reason for) our indignation and so I asked all GCC partners to do what they can to resolve the problem," he said.
